bug.short_desc: [1.8][compiler] Missing compile error in Java 8 mode for Interface.super.field access

long_desc.thetext: Created attachment 247252 Patch

Created attachment 247256 Patch
All test results are good. Please review.
Shankha, please add tests for all relevant snippets from both sections. I'll review once Jay finishes testing, Thanks

Comments:
- Message could simply be "Illegal access to super interface field" - llegalFieldAccessForInterface ==> IProblem.IllegalSuperInterfaceFieldAccess - Change method name also accordingly. - We don't have a isQualifiedSuper() method. It would be better to add it rather than say this.receiver.isSuper() && !this.receiver.isUnqualifiedSuper() - Junits for all relevant snippets from JLS

(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #5) Because of this sentence in JLS 8 15.11.2: "It is a compile-time error if the current class is not an inner class of class T or T itself."
In C#foo(), the current class is C, which is not an inner class of T, nor T itself.
In the second example, the current class is C, which has an enclosing class S. Neither of those is T, hence the compile error.
Those examples are equivalent to this line in comment 0:
System.out.println(S.super.f); // compile error (correct)

Created attachment 247339 alternative patch (without tests)
(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #2) > Created attachment 247256 [details] [diff] > Patch
In comment 0, I would actually expect an IProblem.IncorrectEnclosingInstanceReference as it was before Java 8 and like for "S.super.f". No need for a new error message and no need for mentioning default methods.
Organize Imports currently adds an unused import for the invalid reference "T.super.f" because "f" resolves to a field (even with the patch). "f" and the SuperFieldAccess node should not resolve to anything.
I think the actual problem is that QualifiedSuperReference#findCompatibleEnclosing(..) sets currentCompatibleType, but a FieldReference should never see that currentCompatibleType (because it's only applicable to message invocations).
Since QualifiedSuperReference doesn't seem know about its enclosing FieldReference, I didn't see a quick way to implement the fix there. But a fix in FieldReference#resolveType(BlockScope) seems to work fine, see the alternative patch.

Created attachment 247344 Patch
(In reply to Markus Keller from comment #6) Thank you Markus.
(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #4) All the changes have been incorporated.
I have added few more test cases.
(In reply to Markus Keller from comment #7) Will study the patch.
Thanks

Created attachment 247345 Patch
Updated Copyright entries. Please see Comment 8 for details regarding the patch.
Thanks

(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #10) > (In reply to Markus Keller from comment #7) > > Created attachment 247339 [details] > > alternative patch (without tests)
I will check if the following check helps: this.receiver.isQualifiedSuper()

(In reply to Markus Keller from comment #7)
> Organize Imports currently adds an unused import for the invalid reference > "T.super.f" because "f" resolves to a field (even with the patch). "f" and > the SuperFieldAccess node should not resolve to anything.
It should not resolve to a _valid_ field binding, it should instead resolve to a ProblemFieldBinding with its closest match set to the valid binding with a suitable problem reason. I think this should take care of the unused import problem.

(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #10) This can easily be fixed in the alternative patch by starting the check with:
if (this.receiver instanceof QualifiedSuperReference && ...
(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #12) > a ProblemFieldBinding with its closest match set to the valid binding with a > suitable problem reason. I think this should take care of the unused import > problem.
ImportReferencesCollector shouldn't have looked at the field name anyway. Fixed with http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.ui.git/commit/?id=cd0b9eef301c91a66389175f522ba57a55599dd8
The new problemID is not necessary and should not be added. The problem is not the access to this specific field, but that there's no enclosing instance of T.
I think having bindings for the T.super.f and the f is also not too helpful, since this resolution doesn't make sense for a SuperFieldAccess. But I could live with that if the error is changed to
scope.problemReporter().noSuchEnclosingInstance(this.actualReceiverType, this.receiver, false);

(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #15) You seem to assume that "T.super.f" has anything to do with the new super method invocation variant from JLS8 15.12.1. But that's not the case. Super field access has not changed in any way with JLS8, and it would be confusing if our error messages would suggest such a connection.
The errors for T.super.f and S.super.f should be the same.

(In reply to Markus Keller from comment #16) > (In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #15) > You seem to assume that "T.super.f" has anything to do with the new super > method invocation variant from JLS8 15.12.1. But that's not the case. Super > field access has not changed in any way with JLS8, and it would be confusing > if our error messages would suggest such a connection. > > The errors for T.super.f and S.super.f should be the same.
I was simply pointing out that it will be confusing to say there is no enclosing instance. X implements T and X and T both lexically enclose the reference site.
The proposed alternate message avoids all this confusion.

(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #17) And what about "S.super.f" in your example? It's exactly the same case, and it should use exactly the same message. I think it's clear that the term "enclosing instance" doesn't mean the "zeroth enclosing instance". That's the same usage as in all other error messages that contain "enclosing".
The IncorrectEnclosingInstanceReference message could be clarified like this: 22 = No enclosing instance of class {0} is accessible in scope
The message "Illegal access to super interface field" has quite a few problems:
- "Illegal access" doesn't help me find out what's wrong. Why is it illegal? Because of API tools restrictions? Because of visibility constraints? Or because there's no lexically enclosing instance of type T? Third one would be correct, but your message doesn't reveal that at all.
- "super interface field" doesn't make sense. Such a field doesn't exist. But your message tells me that a "super interface field" exists and that it's just not accessible. That's wrong.

(In reply to Markus Keller from comment #18)
> The message "Illegal access to super interface field" has quite a few > problems:
Shankha, please proceed with the suggestions from Markus and prepare a final patch, TIA.

(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #20) > Created attachment 247400 [details]
Test Results are good. Please review.
Will add few more test cases.

Created attachment 247477 Patch
Added few more test cases and removed secondary errors. Please look at Comment 20 for details regarding the patch.
Please review.
Thanks
I have filed a bug against javac. Once it is accepted I will update with the Bug id.
*** Bug 445049 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created attachment 247636 Patch
Test case added for Bug Bug 445049. Please look at Comment 20 for details regarding the patch. Please review.
Thanks

Created attachment 247914 Alternate patch under test
Shankha, can you take a look at this - I think this is the orthodox way to fix it. Can you test if the bogus import problem reported by Markus happens with this patch ?
This is still under test.
All tests pass, Shankha, if you don't find any issues with this patch, Please go ahead and release and resolve, Thanks.
For completeness, we should also add isQualifiedSuper to MessageSend, though it is no relevant to this bug.

(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #29) > For completeness, we should also add isQualifiedSuper to MessageSend, though > it is no relevant to this bug.
The method has been added to MessageSend.
(In reply to Srikanth Sankaran from comment #27) > Shankha, can you take a look at this - I think this is the orthodox way > to fix it. Can you test if the bogus import problem reported by Markus > happens with this patch ?
The import problem (Comment 13) is fixed with the patch.
Commit: http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=92d8872e8a618ddba36d41f3d903f6d211bf20ba
Thanks

(In reply to shankha banerjee from comment #24) > I have filed a bug against javac. Once it is accepted I will update with the > Bug id.
I guess that bug is still in Oracle's inscrutable queue. If you still have the bug title and text, please paste it here, so that we know what has been reported.
(In reply to Markus Keller from comment #31) I do not remember the bug title. I will try and check if there is a support mailing list. Will remember to post the details on bugzilla from next time.
Verified for Eclipse Mars 4.5M3 Build id: I20141027-2000
